title-group.subtitle: A Note on a Latent Variable Modeling Approach

abstract.p: A latent variable modeling approach that permits estimation of propensity scores in observational studies containing fallible independent variables is outlined, with subsequent examination of treatment effect. When at least one covariate is measured with error, it is indicated that the conventional propensity score need not possess the desirable property of bias adjustment with respect to possible prior group differences. For this setting, a modified propensity score is discussed that is based on true scores on fallible covariates and perfectly measured covariates, if available. This modified score can be recommended to use for average treatment effect evaluation in circumstances where selection into groups occurs on corresponding underlying latent dimensions measured with error. The proposed propensity score procedure is illustrated with an example.

body.p: Observational studies are frequently conducted in the behavioral, educational, social, and biomedical sciences. This is often the case when evaluation of the effect of a certain treatment, therapy, prevention, program, or intervention is of concern. A main reason for the popularity of these studies is the fact that in these disciplines it is frequently rather difficult if at all possible to assign randomly studied subjects to treatment conditions. This serious limitation is typically due to a number of important ethical, practical, feasibility, organizational, or related reasons (e.g., Rubin, 2008; Shadish, Cook, & Campbell, 2002). Rosenbaum and Rubin (1983) proposed the propensity score (PS) that can be used to adjust statistically for differences between treatment and control groups, which can be explained in terms of given independent variables (usually referred to as “covariates” in an observational study setting). Since then, the use of PSs has been becoming increasingly widespread in empirical investigations concerned with treatment effect evaluation in the educational and psychological disciplines (e.g., Guo & Fraser, 2010).

Optimal features of the PS in adjusting for preexisting group differences and unbiased estimation of average treatment effect have been demonstrated in case of precisely measured covariates (cf. Rosenbaum & Rubin, 1983; see also Rubin, 2008). Perfectly reliable covariates are, however, an exception rather than the rule in social and behavioral research. In the latter, as is well-known, it is far more often the case that at least one of the independent variables is associated with substantial unreliability because of sizeable error of measurement.

The aim of this note is to discuss an extension of the traditional concept of PS to the case when at least one of the covariates used cannot be evaluated precisely while their underlying latent dimension(s) contributes to group selection (cf. Kaplan, 1999; Steiner, Cook, & Shadish, 2011). Below, we describe a modified propensity score (MPS) that can be estimated using the framework of the popular latent variable modeling (LVM) methodology. The associated estimation procedure can be readily used to account for measurement error in covariates employed in observational studies concerned with evaluation of effects of a conducted treatment, therapy, prevention, or intervention (referred to generically as “treatment” in the sequel), which are oftentimes of special interest in educational, behavioral, social, and biomedical research.

sec.title: Propensity Scores and Covariates
sec.p: A characteristic feature of empirical studies in the social and behavioral disciplines is that one can rarely carry out random assignment to treatment and/or control conditions. There are multiple reasons of ethical or practical nature that can lead to this limitation (e.g., Rubin, 2008; Shadish et al., 2002). In addition, oftentimes recruited subjects already have values on certain covariates related to examined response variables, which values cannot be manipulated, changed, or controlled. For these reasons, such investigations are frequently referred to as observational studies (e.g., Rosenbaum, 2002). In these circumstances, given that preexisting group differences may lead to such on the dependent (response, outcome) variable that are over and above those due to an examined treatment, or in lieu of it, a question of main relevance is whether there may be a possibility to account for those prior differences when evaluating the treatment effect. Over the past nearly 30 years, the concept of PS (Rosenbaum & Rubin, 1983) has become popular in such studies as a means of adjusting for preexisting group differences, and is of particular importance for the remainder of this article.

sec.title: Propensity Score With Perfectly Measured Covariates
sec.p: Treatment effect evaluation in observational studies with no random assignment requires that comparisons be made across treatment and control groups in an unbiased way, that is, in a way adjusting for their possible differences due to sources other than the treatment under consideration. To accomplish this aim, Rosenbaum and Rubin (1983) introduced the concept of PS. To define it here, it is helpful to briefly describe first the notion of a balancing score (BS) that is more general than that of PS, with the PS being a special case of BS.

In the following discussion, we will be concerned with the case of single treatment and control groups and a response variable, denoted y, which represents a setup frequently of concern in empirical, behavioral, and social research (see Conclusion section for an extension). Equation (3) is true in a randomized experiment (e.g., Shadish et al., 2002), that is, the SITA condition is fulfilled in randomized experimental studies, where also each subject in a population under consideration has a nonzero probability of receiving each treatment involved (or being assigned to a control group). However, the SITA condition is typically not known to hold in an observational study because of possible prior differences on the covariates as mentioned earlier.

Rosenbaum and Rubin (1983) demonstrated further that when the SITA condition holds in an observational study, then at any value of the BS the difference between the treatment and control means represents an unbiased estimate of the mean (average) treatment effect, E(y1) −E(y0) (at that BS value), where E denotes expectation with respect to the pertinent population. This result is a main motivation for the popularity of the PS in observational studies. The reason is that it implies that pair matching, subclassification, and covariance adjustment on a BS can produce unbiased estimates of the average treatment effect in observational studies (e.g., Schafer & Kang, 2008). Specifically, when SITA holds, subjects from different groups but with the same value of a BS can act as controls for one another, that is, the expected difference in their responses equals the average treatment effect of main interest.

sec.title: Conventional Propensity Score With Fallible Covariates
sec.p: Suppose in a given observational study, one were interested in using say p covariates that are measured perfectly (i.e., without error), in addition to q covariates that are fallible, that is, measured with error (p≥ 0, q > 0). Denote these covariates correspondingly by X1, . . ., Xp and V1, . . ., Vq, and their vector by u = (X1, . . ., Xp, V1, . . ., Vq)′. Using the framework of classical test theory (CTT; e.g., Lord & Novick, 1968), the well-known decomposition

holds, where Tj and dj are the true and error scores, respectively, associated with the observed score Vj (j = 1, . . ., q; e.g., Raykov & Marcoulides, 2011). If one knew the true scores Tj on all fallible covariates for all studied subjects, and these scores were relevant for selection into groups (group assignment), then one could consider the PS based on the variables X1, . . ., Xp, T1, . . ., and Tq. This PS would then be particularly useful under SITA (with regard to X1, . . ., Xp, T1, . . ., and Tq). However, the true scores Tj are typically unknown in an empirical study, and instead of them only their observed scores Vj are available (j = 1, . . ., q). sec.title: Modified Propensity Score With Fallible Covariates
sec.p: To accommodate the case of fallible covariates within the PS framework, we propose a modification of the traditional PS in Equation (2), when at least one of the covariates considered is measured with error (and group selection occurs on the underlying latent dimension[s], as is often the case in empirical educational and psychological research).

sec.p: To ensure identification of an instrumental model defined below (Equation 7), which allows the resulting MPS to be estimated in an empirical setting, we assume that for each fallible covariate at least two indicators are made available that measure the corresponding underlying latent dimension (true score).1 Specifically, the rest of this article assumes that for each fallible covariate Vj with a true score Tj, at least a pair of congeneric measures are accessible that evaluate the same underlying true score Tj (1 ≤j≤q; Jöreskog, 1971). Since Equation (7) involves latent as well as observed variables, it defines a latent variable model (e.g., Muthén, 2002). This model can be fitted using say the popular latent variable software Mplus (Muthén & Muthén, 2010). sec.title: Evaluation of Average Treatment Effect
sec.p: As discussed at length in the literature (e.g., Rosenbaum & Rubin, 1983; Rubin, 2008; Shadish et al., 2002; Steiner et al., 2011), the PS can be used in a number of ways for evaluation of a treatment effect of concern, including in particular: (a) subclassification, (b) matching, (c) as a covariate in a model relating the response variable y to available covariates and group membership z (possibly adding the interactions of the latter with each of the covariates as further predictors in that model; see Illustration on Data section).

Each of these three listed approaches, (a) through (c), as well as other possibilities of using the CPS for treatment evaluation if any, are also available with the MPS described in this article once estimated (see Equation 10 and below), when it is to be used as a means for adjusting for prior group differences in observational studies with fallible covariates (e.g., Schafer & Kang, 2008). In the remainder of this article, we will be concerned with approach (c) (see Kaplan, 1999, regarding (a); and Peikes, Moreno, & Orzol, 2008, regarding (b)).

sec.p: The two-group latent variable model in Equation (7), with the measurement invariance condition imposed, was found to be associated with the following tenable fit indexes when fitted to this data set: chi-square (χ2) = 22.937, degrees of freedom (df) = 24, p value (p) = .524, and root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) = 0 with a 90% confidence interval [0, .049]. These results suggested plausibility of the MI condition in both groups, consistent with measurement of the same pair of true scores—T1 and T2—in both groups. (The Mplus source code needed for fitting this model is presented in Appendix B.)

The two latent means in the treatment group, representing the means of T1 and T2 there, were thereby estimated as 3.029 (0.230) and 2.887 (0.228) (standard errors given in parentheses); these estimates were each associated with a p value < .001. (The latent means were by default set at 0 in the control group; Muthén & Muthén, 2010.) These findings indicate significant group differences on each of the two true scores T1 and T2, with the cases in the treatment group having on average markedly higher such scores than those in the control group, an expected result given the above simulation process.

Since the individual cases’ true scores are known here, straightforward univariate t tests and a multivariate t test could also be conducted on them across groups to evaluate the extent of true group differences (e.g., Johnson & Wichern, 2002). The unidimensional t tests revealed significant group differences along each of the two latent dimensions, with t-test statistics being as follows: t1 = −21.767 (p < .001) and t2 = −19.798 (p < .001) for T1 and T2, respectively. (No less important, comparison of the 95% confidence intervals for the mean group differences suggested that the treatment group was markedly higher on average than the control group: for T1 this interval was [−1.565, −1.306], and for T2 it was [−1.390, −1.139].) Similarly, significant true group differences were found on the two-dimensional true score vector T = (T1, T2), with associated test statistic F(2, 497) = 255.556 (p < .001). Last, significant group differences were also indicated on the response variable y, with a corresponding t-test statistic t = −4.832 (p < .001), whereby the pertinent 95% confidence interval [−2.236, −.943] also revealed marked average group differences.2

Examination of the group distributions of the (estimated) MPS revealed marked similarity in their descriptive characteristics and shape (cf. Rubin, 2008; Schafer & Kang, 2008). In particular, the control group was associated with an average MPS of .719 whereas the treatment group with an average MPS of .720. Furthermore, the standard deviations of the control MPS was 0.014 whereas that of the treatment MPS was 0.016. Hence, the mean group difference in MPS was only 7% of their weighted average standard deviation (cf. Rubin, 2001). This result indicated substantial group overlap. In addition, the two groups had identical ranges, interquartile ranges and maximum scores, nearly identical minimum scores, as well as nonsignificant skewness and kurtosis coefficients. These findings showed pronounced comparability of the treatment and control groups on the (estimated) MPS. (Such group comparability on a PS has been the main reason why the concept of PS has been recommended for use in empirical studies; e.g., Schafer & Kang, 2008.)

Next, direct covariate adjustment—amounting to regression analysis with a response variable y and predictors V1 through V6 as well as group membership—yielded a nonsignificant average treatment effect, as presented in Table 2 (see also Note 3). sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: This article was concerned with a LVM approach for estimation of PSs, with subsequent examination of average treatment effects in observational studies characterized by fallible independent variables and group selection on underlying latent dimensions. Initially, it was indicated that when at least one of the used covariates is measured with error, the CPS need not possess the desirable property of bias adjustment with respect to possible prior group differences (see also Steiner et al., 2011). To address this limitation of the traditional PS, an MPS was then described based on perfectly measured covariates, if available, and true score estimates associated with fallible covariates.

The proposed MPS estimation procedure complements recent research by Steiner et al. (2011), in that here we described a multiple (rather than single) indicator-based LVM estimation procedure for PSs. The present method, being based on more than one indicator per latent variable (dimension) associated with fallible covariates, is specifically designed to capitalize on modeling advantages that accrue from use of the popular LVM methodology with multiple construct measures, when covariates are evaluated with error. Similarly, this MPS procedure complements earlier work by Kaplan (1999) employing MIMIC models in conjunction with a PS obtained beforehand based only on observed covariates (and assumed measured without error). This is because the present article has dealt with a PS built on true scores associated with (common to) each fallible covariate and possible observed perfectly measured covariates.

We stress also that the approach of this article remains true to the “spirit” of PS as originally proposed by Rosenbaum and Rubin (1983). This is because the discussed MPS is estimated without any reference to the outcome (response) variable(s) and is completely unrelated to it (see also Rubin, 2008). This is accomplished by obtaining the estimated MPS from a model that is not an overall one, in that it does not include the response variable(s) (cf. Steyer & Partchev, 1998).

The MPS of this article is equally applicable when more than a single dependent variable is considered of importance in a setting under consideration. The reason is that this MPS is based only on covariates (and true scores associated with them) and hence does not imply any restrictions with regard to the response variable(s). The latter variable(s) (a) can be one or more in number, (b) may or may not be measured with error, and (c) may be associated with any type of latent structure—if of relevance in a given empirical study (with more than 1 dependent variable). In particular, the response variables can themselves comply with a latent variable model (e.g., measurement/factor analysis model; Kaplan, 2007). Last but not least, latent variables can be considered as response variables, if consistent with a research question pursued (cf. Kaplan, 1999). In each of these extensions of the present MPS approach, a correspondingly extended model needs to be fitted in the final stage of the estimation procedure (average treatment effect evaluation; cf. Equation 11), but the procedure of MPS estimation remains the same as outlined in this article, and is in particular conducted before that model including the response variable(s) is fitted to data (cf. Rubin, 2008). That extended model includes then in a subsequent step the estimated MPS as a separate variable and is readily developed using applicable principles of the LVM methodology (e.g., Kaplan, 2007; Muthén, 2002; Muthén & Muthén, 2010; see also Kaplan, 1999).

Limitations of the outlined PS approach stem from its requirement for large samples. This requirement is shared with the CPS based on fitting a logistic regression model (or another model, such as the probit model), and results from their being grounded in an asymptotic statistical theory. In addition, the described procedure capitalizes on measurement invariance across the groups examined (which condition implies as mentioned no restrictions with regard to mean and covariance matrix group differences on the latent dimensions however) as well as availability of multiple congeneric indicators for each latent dimension evaluated by a fallible covariate (see Note 1 regarding how such indicators can be constructed in an empirical study; cf. Kaplan, 1999; Raykov & Marcoulides, 2011).

We encourage future research addressing the issue of specific conditions under which the proposed MPS outperforms the CPS (and traditional covariate adjustment), as well as the possible dependence of the MPS performance on sample size, degree of potential violation of measurement invariance, number of indicators and their reliability, omitted covariates and covariate selection, missing values, as well as misspecified models and other functions of fallible covariates. Similarly, since the estimated MPS (Equation 10) is used in the end for treatment effect evaluation, this MPS contains error of estimation that promulgates that inferential process at the testing stage. One can submit that this error will be smaller in cases where the fallible covariates are associated with higher commonality, leading to better true score estimates (Johnson & Wichern, 2002; Raykov & Marcoulides, 2008). Future research should also shed light on this relationship.

In conclusion, this article discussed an approach to handling the case of fallible covariates in PS analysis, which aims to complement the available methods within this analytic framework. An essential feature of the outlined approach is that the estimation of the PS proceeds in a fashion unrelated to the outcome variable, and for this reason represents a two-step procedure similar to the overwhelming majority of methods in PS analysis for treatment effect evaluation (cf. Rosenbaum & Rubin, 1983; Rubin, 2008). The resulting PS estimate is possible to use subsequently in any way that an alternative CPS could be used in empirical research—that is, also for matching and stratification (in addition to covariate adjustment, as in the illustration section). The proposed approach is available for in-depth simulation or other studies that would compare it in a comprehensive manner to available alternative methods of PS and treatment effect estimation and address further the above mentioned limitations of the discussed MPS.

(These indicators are the Ws in the following discussion in the main text.) A larger number of such indicators can also be obtained by splitting the original scale into more than two parcels, if possible (cf. Raykov & Marcoulides, 2011). This multiple-indicator context, which underlies the developments in the rest of the article, represents a main difference between the present approach and that by Steiner et al. (2011).

All cited test statistics in this paragraph of the main text are significant also after a multiple-testing adjustment of significance level used, for example, after employing Bonferroni’s alpha correction procedure (and thus using a significance level α = .05/6 = .0083; e.g., Johnson & Wichern, 2002).

The same pattern of results is found when including in the fitted model (Equation 11) also the interactions of group membership (z) with each of the covariates used, for the first two analyses reported in the main text (presented in Tables 2 and 3) as well as when the interaction of group membership with the (estimated) true scores is included in the last fitted model there (presented in Table 4). Similarly, with the CPS adjustment procedure—using in addition the CPS based on the fallible covariates only, along with their interactions with z—the group membership variable is associated with p = .704, that is, remains nonsignificant.
